entry.et: Middle English, from Old English weorthan; akin to Old High German werdan to become, Latin vertere to turn, Lithuanian versti to overturn, Sanskrit vartate he turns

def.dt: :become usually used in the phrase woe worth

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English weorth worthy, of (a specified) value; akin to Old High German werd worthy, worth

def.dt: :having monetary or material value
:estimable
:to the fullest extent of one's value or ability
:monetary value farmhouse and lands of little worth
:the equivalent of a specified amount or figure a dollar's worth of gas
:the value of something measured by its qualities or by the esteem in which it is held a literary heritage of great worth
:moral or personal value trying to teach human worth
:merit excellence a field in which we have proved our worth
:wealth riches
:equal in value to
:having assets or income equal to
:deserving of well worth the effort
:of substantial or significant value or merit
:the concept that women and men should receive equal pay for jobs calling for comparable skill and responsibility
:self-esteem
city N Texas W of Dallas pop 534,694
city SE Florida on Lake Worth (lagoon) S of W. Palm Beach pop 35,133
:an opinion offered on a topic under discussion send your two cents' worth to your senator
:a sum or object of very small value :practically nothing said angrily that for two cents he'd punch your nose
inlet (lagoon) of the Atlantic SE Florida
